justification: The article notes that in "the card selection task shown in Fig. 1e … participants typically fail to seek key falsifying evidence," behaviour that is "consistent with a large literature indicating that humans suffer from confirmatory decision biases (Nickerson 1998)."

Describing Fig. 1d, the paper reports that when participants decided which holiday to accept or reject they "simultaneously preferred and dispreferred one of the options, a logical impossibility (Shafir 1993)," demonstrating a preference-reversal effect measured with the accept-vs-reject holiday choice task.

The text gives the classic example where "participants might choose between a sure bet of $3000 and an 80 % chance for $4000 … participants often show a preference for safer lotteries with lower expected value, a phenomenon known as risk aversion."

It is stated that "participants will typically only accept lotteries involving a 50:50 chance of gaining X or losing Y when the amount X is approximately twice Y … This entails that losses are subjectively weighted more heavily … a phenomenon known as loss aversion."
